intro: Solanum indicum var. carvalhoi, commonly known as the Brazilian nightshade, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a shrub or small tree that typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are usually white or pale purple in color. Its fruit is a small, fleshy berry that turns red when ripe. The species is part of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and contains alkaloids, making it potentially toxic if ingested.
